explanation: The report is correct. The code computes max as pp->buffer_size - pp->buffer_pos using size_t; if pp->buffer_pos > pp->buffer_size this subtraction underflows (wraps to a very large value). The subsequent clamp (if (max > post_data_len - poff) max = post_data_len - poff;) may reduce the copy length, but it does not fix the destination pointer arithmetic: memcpy(&buf[pp->buffer_pos], &post_data[poff], max) will use a destination pointer that points past the end of the allocated buffer (buf + pp->buffer_size). That can cause writes beyond the object bounds and therefore is a violation of MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17. (The same class of issue could also affect the later memmove calls if pp->buffer_pos or ioff have unexpected values.) To comply, the code must ensure pp->buffer_pos <= pp->buffer_size (or otherwise validate and guard the subtraction) before using the result in pointer arithmetic and library calls.
